												Back in the day I was dissapointed Fallout Tactics wasn't a 'real' roleplaying game like Fallout 1 & 2. Being a huge fan of the series I still gave this game a try and I wasn't dissapointed to say the least.Fallout Tactics, like the name already says, is a tactical game in the Fallout universe. You start by creating your main character and give him/her the skills you prefer. You start out with 2 other squad members and as the game progresses your squad members level up so you can adjust their skills like all (PC) Fallout games. After each mission you enter the worldmap to go to different locations like you're bunker where you can recruit new squad members and/or buy/sell equipment. Squad members can ofcourse die and won't return (unless you load your savegame).What sets Fallout Tactics apart from other tactical games for me:1. The variety of enemies. Sometimes you'll be battling Bugs, the other time you will be facing Super Mutants and several other enemies I won't name here (spoilers). Every enemy calls for a different approach. 2. The variety of missions. Sometimes you will have to rescue people, sometimes you have to do an escort mission. Also in most missions you've got a vehicle at your disposal.3. The variety of weapons. Fallout Tactics has a huge range of weapons, both realistic and unrealistic but they all fit in the game nicely.4. The use of skills in a game. Lockpicking, Healing, Defusing... it's all there. 5. Different 'races'. Your squad may also contain different kinds of races like ghouls and Super Mutants. All of them ofcourse have their own speciality/skills.6. Gameplay. The tactical combat just works really well in this game as a tactical game should obviously. Everytime you make a clean kill feels very good.7. Graphics. The graphics have aged very well in my opinion. Blood and gore is ofcourse included and every kill feels satisfying.8. Last but not least; The Fallout universe.Simply put in my opinion Fallout Tactics is still the best tactical game out there. Although I have to admit it's partially due the Fallout universe. I have played the XCOM series and Jagged Alliance and this game is still number 1 in my book.

												Fallout Tactics emphasizes tactical combat and strategy but limited interactions with non-player characters, but they can still be traded with. Instead of towns, Fallout Tactics centers around Brotherhood bunkers and missions. The bunkers serve as a central point for the Brotherhood, and players can obtain the services of quartermasters, mechanics, personnel yeomen, and medics.Combat in Fallout Tactics is a bit more complicated than the previous two Fallout games. Unlike those, which featured an individual turn-based system, Fallout Tactics features three combat types: Continuous Turn-Based (everyone can act at the same time, and action points are regenerated at a rate based on Agility), Individual Turn-Based (used in the original games) and Squad Turn-Based (each turn is given to a squad and include the ability to change stance, modifiers for height, and setting sentry modes).Fallout Tactics is also the first of the Fallout games to feature a multi-player mode. In this mode, each player controls a squad of characters and faces off against opposing players. During game setup, players are granted a number of points with which to purchase squad members and gear.Although the main character in the single player game has to be human, recruits from the brotherhood and characters in multiplayer matches can be of any of the six races featured in the game. Humans, Super Mutants, Ghouls, Deathclaws, Dogs or Humanoid Robots.

												Squad-based tactical game in the universe of Fallout, with post-nuclear war havoc reigns the world, and you have to fight the hordes of Chaos in the name of Order. To be precise, you gotta kill much in the name of Brotherhood of Steel. But I guess you've figured that out by yourself, simple by reading the name of the game. I'll say even more of obvious things now, so for those who are short-in-temper for reading, I suggest to skip to the bottom right away.I remember that at time when it was released, the plenty of critics were against it. They were very angry with that approach on beloved universe of Fallout 1&2, which ruined one of the brightest RPG experience ever... That was common thought back than.Now it's 2016 year, it's been 15 years after game's release. What's the situation now, why there are so many positive reviews on Steam, why people still enjoying the game, that was almost completely sinked after release? There are two main answers: first, it is still branded as Fallout game, even if the story is not "canonical". Classic nonetheless, as people say. Now, the second reason... surprisingly, it is a fair tactical game! Certainly not the best in the genre, but hey! - all good games in that "tactical" genre you can count with your fingers! Every working approach there worth its money!Certainly, Fallout Tactics is not for everyone. If you don't like games where you need to clear levels from enemies in the quite slow-paced turn-by-turn style, just pass by. And even if you are good with turn-based combats, in the most cases, I'd recommend you to buy and play Wasteland 2 instead. It is providing much better experience for much wider auditory.Fallout Tactics has many downsides. The story tastes... not fresh, and even not-satisfying. The battle system is good, but not calculated enough. The worst part of it is moving in turn-based mode: the maps are big, and your legs are quite short! What's even worse, the bugs with way-mapping still there, just like I remember them from 2001 year. The skills and all other SPECIAL system from the original Fallout also not fitting in, considering the fact it is not a proper RPG, but rather a "shoot'em all" pattern turn-based combat simulator.But... all of those minuses are manageble, if you have some temper and will. All but one, the final of the story there is way worse than in the Fallout 3. So, even strongest by will cannot really vouch for replayablity in that game. Unless they are not bothering with the story at all.Multiplayer could be a mind-blowing thing, but no. Not even the possibility to ride deathclaws can fix some real difficulties with combat system and the possibility to connect with other players (its LAN only now, servers are gone)... Simply put, there is no fun. You'd be much better with XCom Enemy Unknown multiplayer, by any reason.So. Why you can buy that game? Obviously, the main reason, for it goes in the bundle with the main games, Fallout 1&2. I even remember some events when the keys for that trio (F1, F2 and F tactics) were distributed free of charge...Why play it? Well, if you have a thing for turn-based squad tactical games, with lots of guns, and big maps filled with all the menagerie of Wasteland... Give the game a shot, it is worth one. Like I already said, there are too few of decent squad-based tactical games, to turn up your nose against it.My rating is 69/100, for I forget nothing.

												Let's start this review off by saying that this game has a very mixed reputation, and for a very good reason.Fallout Tactics isn't like its forefathers Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Fallout Tactics is a strategy game, and unlike its forefathers, has no speech skill, no major RPG elements, and more straightforward, action based gameplay. It has a very unique story, and is so far the only Fallout game that has its setting in the Midwestern United States.Fallout Tactics has voiceacted dialog, unlike Fallout 1 and 2. Fallout Tactics also offers four difficulty settings, Easy, Normal, Hard, and Insane. Easy is about what you would expect, easy, it makes the game very very easy and significantly more easygoing. Normal isn't much different, but it too offers a more story and action based game than the two harder difficulties. Hard is a minor step up from Normal, forcing you to play more adaptively, and sparringly with your supplies, as vendors either don't restock, or you have to complete a mission for them to, making supplies very restricted if you waste them. Insane is exactly what you would expect, insane. It's borderline impossibly hard if you play with Tough Guy Mode turned on, which I will touch on in a second. Insane mode drops your accuracy by a flat 20%, halves your average damage, curbs your chance to get criticals to extremely low, doubles enemy damage, resistence, accuracy, and worst of all, the enemy will get critical hits with frightening frequency. Strategy is everything on Insane. Your supplies become even more limited, and you will die many many many times, which makes Tough Guy even more bitter.Tough Guy Mode makes it so you can only save when you are in a bunker, which makes Mission 1 extremely frustrating and bitter. You start off not in a bunker, with no autosave for the character you made, meaning if you die, you're going to have to remake your character all over again. Some people would say that's a very poor design choice, and I'm inclined to agree. Tough Guy Mode is something I have only ever played Fallout Tactics with turned on, extra difficulty and in this case, a Resident Evil style restrictive save system appeals to my nostalgia for difficulty driven older games. It's not too frustrating on all 3 of the easier difficulties, but on Insane, it's definitely going to make you angry once or twice per level, because there are going to be more than a few occassions in which you're going to either lose a character, or die and have to restart, due to bad luck with criticals or missing a shot you desperately needed to hit.Fallout Tactics also comes with an editor which you can use to mod and edit the game yourself, and it's extremely well made, and isn't hard at all to learn how to use. Among the few things you can do with it, you can remedy the frustration of Mission 1 on Tough Guy Mode by checking a box in the editor that registers Mission 1 as a "bunker" which allows you to save after you make your character, open the editor, turn it off, and after that it's up to you, as you can save whenever you want for the duration of that specific save game's Mission 1, or you can save once immediately after making your character and never do it again out of honor, it's a way to alleviate the tedious nature of having to recreate your character multiple times if you're playing on a harder difficulty. The editor's readme.txt offers a fully comprehensible manual on what you need to do to use the editor, including details on what files you need to extract.There is also a mod for Fallout Tactics that's very very similar to the Restoration Project in that it revamps a lot of the games issues and kinks, and all in all the Redux Mod, as it's called, is very well made, if albeit a bit more difficult in general, namely a few enemies are inserted into very cheap places, like corners, with weapons that have the potential to kill you instantly, and on Mission 1, with TG turned on, you can probably imagine why that will drive you crazy, which is namely what made me abuse the life out of savescumming on M1 with TG on on Insane, as both remaking my character, and the possibility of having to restart the level over and over again due to cheap enemy placement wore its welcome out very very quickly.Charisma is also a significantly more important stat than in the previous games, or maybe not, that varies on if you used to have a posse of companions in F1 and 2. Charisma in Fallout Tactics dictates how quickly you will advance in ranks in the Brotherhood of Steel, which controls the quality of goods the Brotherhood Quartermasters will have, the quality of recruits you will have access to, and also, how soon you acquire Power Armor.The level design is more straight along a single path than previous games, and the sandbox elements are extremely limited. There is also an infamous glitch that's unavoidable in which you will get several random encounters per second, which unless you have 100% Outdoorsman, will drain your already extraordinarily finite resources, which is extremely laborous, and frustrating, as you have the potential to die during one of these, and on Tough Guy, that will send you back to your last save at a bunker. These random encounters aren't particularly unique, or fun either, as they usually consist of the same general enemies that are commonplace for that area, which can range from komodo dragons, to deathclaws, and even just a bunch of ghostly looking civilians. It can be extremely frustratingly tedious.Do I recommend this game? For people that enjoy strategy games, and even just diehard Fallout fans, definitely, it has drawbacks, and many flaws, but then again, doesn't any game?

												Fans of the original Fallout games used to hate this game back in 2001, because they were all waiting for the follow up, that had been brewing for quite some time at the time, to Fallout 2 and then they got this: a bloody amazing Tactical Combat game, but without speech and dialogue.. I loved it, especially the Continous Turn Based (CTB) option coupled with the Aggressive Sentry Modes with variable Accuracy Thresholds. Awesome!! And if the combat got too messy or overwhelming you could always switch to turn-based. Splendid. Finally a game that lets you deal with all the cannonfodder in a nice and easy way. Levels, levels, levels. It was also the best looking Fallout game ever with dynamic lights, even though it was a bit less cozy, cartoony and charming, but the intro is awesome nonetheless and there is a bit of choice along the way, but it's mostly RPG at gun-point. So, obviously the only thing missing here is the Speech skill.. And thus the use and need of Charisma is rather limited - to just the speed of your ranks and bartering. There is also a Tough Guy mode, but the end mission is quite long in itself, which is the reason why I never finished it as Tough Guy - I simply don't have the time to finish the last mission in one session. Combat is more flexible also in turn-based, because you are not stuck on a grid.. It's total free-form-360. There are Sentry modes with four Accuracy Thresholds: 95, 66, 33 and 1% where you team will react automatically. There are also three stance positions: Standing, Crouch and Prone. You can switch all at once, in minor teams or individually and they don't switch from one stance to the other unless you make them.. There are also both Special and Random Encounters (RE) when you travel the wasteland. It's both a blessing and a curse. A blessing because it's a source of EXP, guns and ammo and a curse because at times you'll be really annoyed by the sheer number of it. Having someone with Outdoorsman becomes quite crucial. Every container, which includes both vehicles, boxes, lockers and rercruits at the Recruit Master can be used to store equipment. I think there is a kind of economy in the game that deflates the value of things you sell and therefore it's not a bad idea to pile up huge quantities before dropping them off at the Quarter Master shop. As you progress the number and variation of Recruits at the Recruit Master will grow, but they will not advance unless you "tag" them all at least once. The "tagging" involves adding them all to your team, before you switch them back to the pool of Recruits. That way they will also get Experience, whenever you do and thus will never become too weak to join you. Just remember to come back and advance them. Along the way you will also encounter different vehicles that you can actually bring with you, drive around in and use as armor with your whole team as gun mounts and they can also be used as Storage for all the loot you find - just remember to bring a member with the Repair skill, which you'll need to repair the damage it gets from accidents or RE along the way; having a Pilot is an added bonus. Today, a truly wide-screen adjustment would have been nice, even though I think there is a mod for it I just can't be bothered to install it, somehow.. Well, there are some low res Wide-screen choices (16:9 and 16:10)..  I've played and replayed it a hell of a lot, before it appeared on Steam.The combat of X-COM and Wasteland are just like flies on the windscreen compared to this.

One of the best games I have ever played. I played it already several times over and it brings a nice feeling every time.  The game is a tactical role playing game, if you played XCOM.. it is similar but you tend to get more involved with your team.  The SPECIAL sistem (Strength Perceptio Charisma Inteligence Agility Luck) works very nice.  The game's atmosphere is really immersive.. you can really feel like you're fighting in the wasteland all sorts of enemies while you are pursuing a plot.  Random encounters, bonus objectives plus altering your starting SPECIAL configuration to get different skills and perks for a different gameplay strategy for your main character contributes to get a good replayability. On the minus side, ..  may happen that the game crashes (experienced 2-3 times in 40 hours of gameplay)  Tough Guy is not very attractive.. you can only get 2 extra level up's (10%).. would have preffered the enemies getting tougher + unable to save except for bunkers .. and your character's being able to get  10+ level-ups.. Other remarks.. the game seems to be a bit rushed out.. there are a lot of weapons in the game.. but once you played the game once or twice you will easilly identify the ones that are really good. Some traits are really not usefull.. And some of the secondary skills are underused and I have the feeling that also Luck is underused in the game (with the exception of criticals and getting some specific the perks), also some of the random encounters are not very useful.. I heavilly recommend using the resolution mod and checking out the walktrough from GameBanshee while you are playing this game... it will show you how to unlock the bonus mission and if you end up thrashed and hopeless (for instance when you encounter super mutants for the first time.. maan that's a wake up mission..:)..). Also only play on continuous mode, do not even try turn-based mode since due to the game being rushed out, testers only used continuous mode to do the testing.Every once in a while when I want to set my mind on something else.. I play some FoT .. For me it is perfect.. it's much more specific than Fallout 1 and 2 (you get mission briefings.. and you basically know what you have to achieve), much less head akes than Fallout 3+ (which are more like shooters from my point of view).. but FoT manages to remain so immersive.. and the fact that most of the early equipment is actually real equipment you can buy today makes the feeling even more genuine and relatable. (to the end it gets really Sci-Fi :).. but that's really ok too!)

Posted: February 5
												First, let me clear the air on this one by saying I bought this game when it first came out on disc. Back then I think it was actually shipped on a CD-ROM and not even a DVD, but anyway that's why I show only 6 minutes played. I repurchased this game on Steam and it's a title I will take out every so often and play for a few days, and then set aside again to be enjoyed later. When I first bought the game, I played it pretty intensively, single and multiplayer.The premise of this game is simple but the implementation is amazing. There is a little gem of a game called Final Fantasy Tactics that I used to play on Playstation which was one of my favorites; I think it got over-looked and disrespected to some extent because it was not a traditional Final Fantasy game. It was a game set in the world of Final Fantasy but focused on tactical battles rather than RPG elements, that would take place on small 3D maps where terrain and positioning of your warriors mattered greatly. Fallout Tactics is very much along the same lines: a game set in the world of the Fallout game series, but focused on tactical small-scale combat rather than role-playing. The developers of Tactics did this extremely well!What you have here is a game that captures the fierce joy of the warrior risking his life and fighting to the death. In Tactics, you command a squad of warriors as they fight through a 3D map to accomplish certain objectives. You watch the action from above in isometric view, and directly move and perform actions with each of your squad members in a turn-based style. The maps can be the size of a small town; large enough that it takes some time to work your way across a single battle. Troop positioning and the "lay of the land" is vitally important for your success. Your troops can stand, crouch, and go prone, and move in all those positions, and since the map is rendered in 3D the height of various points of cover and "line of sight" principles mean you can really outmaneuver the enemy (or be outmaneuvered, if you aren't careful!)During the course of the SP game you complete a campaign that progresses in difficulty. You get access to a pool of recruits that you can choose from with different skills, and those skills are honed and developed in combat, so the more you use particular recruits the more powerful they will become. This makes it especially painful if you lose a beloved comrade in combat, as combat deaths are final! All part of the glory, my friend.This game has great graphics for its age and still looks good; it has lots of different weapons and skills you can use to achieve your goals; there is extreme freedom to decide how to tackle each map, just as you would expect from a Fallout title; and there is blood and gore and vicious, bullets-flying, clubs smacking, rockets-exploding combat action that will keep you entertained every minute.I'm not sure how I can else I can say this other than: go ahead and buy this game if you like tactical combat or RTS or Rainbow Six-style squad battles or seeing a man's torso distintegrate into bloody chunks from a close-range shotgun blast.10/10 Find high ground and go for headshots with a scoped rifle!!!

												I suggest any prospective players of Fallout Tactics ignore the rose-tinted nostalgia contained in many of these positive reviews, and realize that even at the time of release Fallout Tactics had a well-deserved reputation as a mediocre knockoff of Fallout 1 and 2. At its core the game is a squad based, isometric RPG with a similar control scheme to Infinity Engine games such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, but it tries to focus almost entirely on large scale combat over the lore, exploration and storytelling that made the original two Fallout games so enjoyable. You generally use the same mechanics, weapons and abilities found in Fallout 2, and even can switch between real-time and the "classic" turn based combat, but the end result feels like a poorly balanced mess. My major complaints:1. Inability to switch from real time to turn based mode outside of combat gives encamped enemies way too much of an advantage2. Movement range in turn based mode is too small for the size of the maps you play on3. Vehicles die too easily and are annoying to control4. Some mission objectives are stupidly vague and NPCs don't give useful context cluesIf it's not clear already, "needlessly slowing down the pace of the game" seems to be a reoccuring theme here. But there are other major areas the game has problems with:5. The plot and characters are generic and unmemorable, and besides that, aren't even considered canon6. Most of the skills outside of combat are uselessDespite these issues I'm not saying this game is all terrible. Being able to use cover and crouch is a cool concept that adds a layer of complexity to the combat system that the original Fallout games did not have. I like being able to play as other races like Deathclaws or Ghouls, they all have their own playstyle quirks that make them feel interesting and distinct. I also like the general concept of epic scale battles against heavily fortified groups of enemies- it's just that the concept was poorly tested and poorly executed. Because this game is not considered canon you are really not missing out on much as a Fallout fan if you decide not to play through it, but if you do I suggest not trying to ramp up the difficulty mode so you can stick with real-time combat (and thus minimize the pacing issues) as much as possible.

For judgement on how this game stands on its own, ignoring comparisons to Fallout 2 (which is actually why most people dislike this game, they didn't get what they wanted, which was Fallout 3 and instead got this combat game), this game isn't really tactical, but it's pretty fun when played as a hack-and-slash sort of playstyle. Playing it with even more specialization than Fallout 2 and 1 is an important part of the game, and makes for a fun sort of roleplaying with how you use weapons and what sort of fighter you are. This gives good replayability, along with decent combat , more or less point-and-click but with some planning and all that.Overall, this game isn't bad for what it is, but you need to know what it is to decide if it's something you'd enjoy. The game's kind of for a niche crowd and a lot of people don't understand that when they're buying the game, and that prevents them from enjoying it. 												Although "Tactics" is built purely around combat, it's no less challenging than its isometric RPG progenitors. You will probably die a lot, and you will probably reload a lot if losing a squad member permanently is unacceptable to you. Mistakes are punished swiftly (and often brutally), and trying to just blast your way through is rarely a workable approach.As a special note, be sure to save often and incrementally. I nearly made it to the end of the game, but was prevented when a defeated enemy blocked the only route to my goal. Unfortunately, I had made my only save just after the enemy was felled, which would have required me to roll back to the beginning of the area to try again. It had been such an exhausting process to get to that point that I just opted to stop playing. (Having put over 60 hours into the game, I figured that I had seen most of the show anyway.)Anyway - this title is a classic example of game design, and definitely worth checking out. It won't "nursemaid" you, but that's part of what made it the experience that it was.

												Okay my least fave of the Fallout originals, if this game can even fall into that description but it is before Bethesda Oblivionised the series. Anyhow... the game does remind me of the cool Fallout 1 and 2, but with far more action and really REALLY shredded story, it is very linear with very few ways to alter the ending. You run a team of 1-6 Characters based on the Fallout 1-2 SPECIAL set up, only the first character is possible to make the rest start out as defaults and you must choose them and improve them or change them into what you want. I prefer to be the Heavy gunner on my own character as it is definatly the weapon that is easiest to cause friendly fire and keeping the rest on single sniping and short range burst to make choke points and a medic with mid-range burst weapons.Now the game can be turned into fallout 1-2 mode, where action points are used on your turn or remain in a sort of fast forward everyone gun down everyone mode which can be highly deadly in the later parts of the game. In the Start however you will enjoy having a 6 man team with hunting rifles sniping the crap out of the enemy before they reach you and it goes fast, but when 3 hover droids with rocket launchers pop up you kinda go.... ZOMG I iz deadz. and it is true, not even power armor can guarantee survivability against a barrage of rockets fired every 2 seconds or so.... in those moments the Fallout 1-2 mode will save your well toasted behind. It strikes me that it might be this mode that made Bethesda make their own version of it for fallout 3 because it is very similar to it, you use your AP up and then it is your next guy in rotations turn, he uses his AP up and then it is the enemies turn... this does give your team a very good chance to kill whatever they are fighting with a few well placed mid-range bursts or Grenadeds.Even if you cheat and make your main guy immortal and a 1 man army with unlimited AP there are missions that requires a team of people to succede because the targets heal each other and are spread across the map, unless all die at the same time it is impossible to succede. The worst downside of the game is however the overland map that is annoying as hell, random encounters happens way to often, and is seriously lacking in usability, you tend to use more resources killing things than what you get.Bottomline: story is meh okay and gameplay is meh okay. Only a true fan of the series would like it enough to beat it and feel that they did not waste time, but as it follows with Fallout 1 and 2 in a bunble it will be worth it.

												Fallout Tactics has a special place in my gaming library. I probably have about a dozen play throughs under my belt since it was originally released and I still keep coming back to it. Sure it's a little buggy and poorly optimized and doesn't have half the depth of Fallout 1 or 2 but it's just such a well constructed tactical game.The real-time-turn-based system is so well balanced and executed it has to be experience to truly appreciate it. The art and aesthetic is 100% Fallout in every way with amazing attention to detail. The game world and story line is huge and well thought out with balanced map design and tons of little interactive set pieces in every encounter. You can play this game different every time as even the smallest mistakes or extra achievements in a mission have an effect on the final outcome.It's a beautiful end of the isometric Fallout games and it may not be a "real" Fallout game in some senses it definitely still has the soul.

												Fallout Tactics is a very focused squad based version of Fallout.You lose alot of the exploration options of Fallout as well as alot of non combative ways to resolve problems. As consequence it is less about losing yourself in the world as it is about kicking the worlds butt.If you like XCOM there is a very good chance you will enjoy this game. For that matter it is probably closer to Jagged Alliance then XCOM but both are great games. The character leveling system is particularly good and challenges you to balance the diffrent skills so that you have a good medic and a good laser guy for example. Unlike other games of the genre there are melee characters (if you permit) on your squad that allow for some stealth elements of the game.Unlike say XCOM the enemy doesn't neccasirly know you are on the map. I like this alot, it is really cool to move your units around a building, in an attempt to prepare for a perfect assult. It is even cooler to have characters sneaking around disabling mines and slitting the throat of a lonely soldier. Dated graphics but defintely worth the time if you like XCOM or Jagged Alliance.

												This game is a mess.I've had several issues with it and plenty are technical issues.The game doesn't run well on newer operation systems and if you want to play fullscreen on windows 8, you'll have to do some glitching in order for it too work.But even then you'll get tearing, lagging and textures popping in and out. Talking about popping in and out, if you're in the open desert and as you walk, enemies will spawn right behin where you just walked. This is especially annoying when you want to clear rooms and suddenly find out that enemies spawned as you left the room, even worse in large areas where the objective is to kill everyone and you have to backtrack to look for those that spawned after you left.Unlike previous Fallout games, you can't see what's in a room when you're not in it. That's fine, if it wasn't so buggy. Enemies will appear and reappear in the room after several seconds of you standing inside of it, you might even just stand right infront of a enemy and have to wait for it to appear so you can kill it.If you're in it for Fallout lore, remember that this game is only semi-cannon and also that there is barely any Fallout here. Sure there are few references to Fallout here and there, many of which are minor and uninteresting.If you're here for the Squad-Based Combat, go elsewhere. Any interactions i've had with the rest of the squad has been unpleasant and annoying. If you're playing in turn-based mode, you'll find that the AI's turns take an insane amount of time, oddly enough, if there are no AIs in the area it still takes alot of time. I playing in real time mode and found that my teammates are more likely to kill themselves and me, rather than the enemy. I abandoned them and played mostly solo, which was more like the other Fallout games and alot more enjoyable.The story seemed like it could be promising but the intro after you start a new game is laughably bad, so much that it's painful to watch. The general, whom you get your missions from, is an awful tough guy cliche. I wish he was muted so i didn't have to listen to him everytime i enter a new mission area. The voice acting is pretty bad and the writing doesn't help either. I especially hate the real world character pictures used for all the characters in the game. It screams low production and i think that's what this game is.Most of the story is told through a picture book with narration but that only happens when major event occur and is honestly the most interest part of the whole thing.Vehicle combat is a thing, it's unresponsive, the vehicle gets stuck, doesn't go where you want it to go and is very buggy. All in all, it's a terrible experience and i'd much rather just not do those missions.I don't intend on finishing this game, it's not worth it. And i think if you want to do yourself a big favor, i would say don't buy this game.

												"I really wanted to like this game...". This is how great many negative reviews start. Before I begin to point out why I am mostly disappointed with Tactics in the range of fresh impressions, I would like to mention I have played the original Fallout and its sequel for a long time before I joined STEAM, enough to get accustomed to them. When I saw Tactics, at first I though the graphics are acceptable to the point that if an utopian Fallout 3 was done with these visuals - yet in the manner of two earlier editions in such aspects as gameplay, plot and hex-based mechanics - I would be satisfied.Unfortunately, soon I learned that within given outlook and layout things as if blend into background, the overall picture seems blurry, images of objects are too small next to being hardly distinctive - and I know how to change resolutions, as well as hopefully my eyesight is fair. Personally, I ultimately find the graphical side unfriendly.I had quite a laugh when I saw that the main characters hair, skin and peripheral elements are customizable in terms of colour. I painted my doll with light-greenish when it comes to skin, black when it comes to hair and underwear-pink when it comes to armor and other stuff. I named it UGLUK, made it a kamikaze-heavyhanded melee outdoorsman-stealth specialist. UGLUK is quite effective in bludgeoning and looting, what this game is all about, just like DIablo 2. "Tactics" is only in the title. Still, I think I would prefer the second one mentioned product in given category, nevertheless have big sympathy and thus expectations of Fallout and post-nuclear themes.The game appears to be thought by developers as swift and intuitive, but it fails here shortly. Neither "continous-turn-based" aka real-time - nor turn based combat are good. The first one is too rapid or loose to be able to carry out simultaneous complex operations within its conditions - as if these were needed at all, but still. Lack of the pause-and-command button is significantly bothersome. The other indicated combat mode feels secondary and slow - since the game is one big combat phase - next to being more difficult.SPECIAL system looks complicated in comparison to the dumbed-down battlescape controls. It has been difficult for me to get into this aspect of Tactics. One accidental wrong click and the turn is lost for an entire squad, along with some equipment waste. Perhaps this "sensitivity" was to be one of the traits of the games "swiftness", unfortunately it is just detrimental. Besides, many options available through key shortcuts are unfeatured on the controls panel, which seem unhandy, especially if to recall the clearness and composure known from the classical two editions. SPECIAL is unproportional for a play that was supposed to be easily graspable. It carries lots of little parameters and tweaks to get into while commanding a raging squad in a run-for-the-hotkey match. The system ought to have been dumbed-down as well, but if it was, the game would become even more like Diablo sequel. But you know, perhaps Diablo 2 is a good pattern after all - at least in some cases - since it achieved a major success, unlike Fallout Tactics?I already mentioned the hex-based battlescape mechanics - characteristic for the two earlier Fallout releases - that the reviewed product lacks. With the actual Tactics solution, it is usually a question where the character will ultimately stand when clicked to set off. Besides, movement is cumbersome in execution - and shines in this regard when addressed to an entire squad. The action - once initiated - is hard to stop. There is a hotkey to cease an ordered procedure, nevertheless it aids to "run for the hotkey" challenge, which the game is full of, especially in "real time" combat mode.Controls, ways of characters responsivity, battlescape mechanics, adjustment of the system, image and visual clarity, legacy - instead of fluently working together for a smooth play, fall onto one another as if in a massive carcrash, creating an obstacle to enjoy the product that otherwise could have been pretty decent. I can hardly get rid of the sense of irony.Cumbersome and unhandy - disrecommended.PS. I am okay with linear plot - just like in case of Diablo 2. At least it should perhaps keep some stable mediocre level - better this than poor execution of overambitious goals.

Posted: June 3, 2013
												Fallout Tactics is not, as many seems to think, the third fallout game. It is a spin-off, set in the time between the two original Fallouts and focusing almost entirely on the one aspect of it's predecessors that was almost universally disliked, squad combat.As you head off into the wasteland one more time you will find some comfort in the familiar. The SPECIAL system is still in place and allows you to customize both yourself and the squad with which you are now required to do battle beside. Memories of NPC burstfiring and having Marcus in your team at all can quickly be dismissed however as your entire squad is completely under your control this time.Battles play out in either the regular turn based mode which with a big team, big maps and lots of enemies make the game dreadfully slow at times, or a pseudo-realtime mode that lets everyone act out their turns in concert with each other. The real time mode might make some of the smaller battles fly past quicker but as it was obviously never part of the core mechanics it comes with a whole slew of problems that makes it unusable when faced with bigger enemy parties, most notably each character will only perform one action at a time and will then stand around afterwards, waiting to be told to fire off his gun for a second time.The great writing of the old Fallout's make a return, although in a more condensed format and lots of the over the top humor from Fallout 2 is present as well making the non-combat segments of the game quite enjoyable, the non-linearity and the choice and consequence system from those games are not present however.Graphically the game feels dated, a long time has passed since the original Fallout and not much has changed since then. The soundtrack still contains some gems and the game does succeed in places at re-creating that Fallout fell. Those instances are unfortunately quite rare.All in all Fallout Tactics is a game that takes too much away from what is tried and true. It tries to create a new experience in a medium with which it has little familiarity and the many rookie mistakes shines through all too much. This makes this a hard game to recommend, even for a die-hard Fallout fan such as myself.

												Now, I do enjoy this game quite a bit, but the fact remains that they've never patched some of the game-breaking bugs that can get you stuck when revisiting a special encounter - such as Bazaar Day or Phil the Nuka Cola Dude. These bugs nearly swayed my recommendation, but it doesn't quite ruin the whole game unless you're a one-save kind of person.Another issue is the slow-paced combat when using the turn-based options, while the continuous turn-based isn't so bad, but it has its drawbacks. For instance, you might be moving two separate groups in an area and might forget another group for long enough for an enemy patrol to come by and open fire on them.Traveling on the world map is another bad experience due to the frequent, almost constant barrage of random encounters. This makes it absolutely vital to level somebody's Outdoorsman skill to 100 or more to give you the option to skip them and continue your journey.It's a decent game, but it has a few nagging drawbacks that keep it from comparing to the first two Fallout games. If you play it, keep these things in mind, as they're quite frustrating at times.
